title: 103_hr4476
content: The "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" is also known as the National Park System Plan. It involves the preparation of a plan for the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Director of the National Park Service, is tasked with preparing a National Park System Plan to guide the direction of the system. The plan includes goals, criteria for resource inclusion, and identification of adequate resource representation. The National Park System Plan outlines criteria for resource inclusion, adequate representation, priorities for adding resources, and the role of the National Park Service. The National Park System Plan includes priorities for adding resources, the role of the National Park Service, and the distinction between different areas within the system. The National Park System Plan outlines outdoor recreation opportunities, defines units of the system, and requires consultation with various stakeholders before being transmitted to Congress. The National Park System Plan requires consultations with stakeholders and public review before being transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years of enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to find better management alternatives, considering factors like duplication, resource representation, significance, feasibility, cost, and visitor accessibility. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated. The Secretary will consider various factors in developing a list of areas in the National Park System that may need modified or terminated management. Recommendations for management by other entities will be made for areas recommended for termination. The Secretary will recommend management by other entities for areas in the National Park System recommended for termination. Consultations with various stakeholders will be conducted to develop the list of areas needing modified or terminated management. The Secretary will consult with various stakeholders, including Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, and the National Park System Advisory Board, to develop recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System. The report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year of completing the plan. The Secretary will consult stakeholders to develop recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System. The report will contain recommendations for alternative management by entities other than the National Park Service and will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units and suggest modifications or terminations to the management. The Commission will consider factors from section 102(a)(2) and present alternative solutions. The United States Senate requires a report listing National Park System units for potential management modifications or termination. The Commission will suggest alternative management by other entities, consult with various stakeholders, and identify feasible alternatives to protect resources and ensure public access. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will consult with stakeholders to develop a list of potential management modifications or termination of National Park System units. Appointments to the Commission will be made by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. The Commission, comprised of 7 members knowledgeable about the National Park System, will appoint a chair from its members and operate with a simple majority quorum. Vacancies will not hinder the Commission's functions, and any vacancies will be promptly filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. The Commission, consisting of 7 members, will appoint a chair from its members and operate with a simple majority quorum. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's functions, and any vacancies will be promptly filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. Meetings will be held quarterly or upon the call of the chair or a majority of members. Members will serve without compensation but will be entitled to travel expenses for official business. The Commission, when engaged in official business, is entitled to travel expenses and per diem. The Commission will terminate 90 days after the report is transmitted to Congress. The Commission can hire staff, with no more than half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission can hire staff, with half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission may procure temporary services and hold public hearings as needed. The Commission has powers to hold public hearings, make bylaws, and use the United States mails. The Secretary must provide requested information to the Commission. The Commission has the power to hold public hearings, make bylaws, and use the United States mails. The Secretary must provide requested information to the Commission regarding relevant duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include general authority, remove certain sentences, authorize appropriations, and add a new subsection for studies of potential park additions. The Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to authorize appropriations and add a new subsection for studies of potential park additions, requiring the Secretary to submit a list of recommended areas for study each year. The Secretary must consider areas with potential for national significance, suitability, and feasibility when developing a list for potential inclusion in the National Park System. Special attention should be given to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the system. Studies for park inclusion must be authorized by Congress, and the National Park Service retains the authority to conduct assessments and provide assistance for nominations. After the date of enactment, the National Park Service can conduct assessments, gather data, provide assistance, and complete surveys for areas requiring less than $25,000. The study for potential National Park System inclusion must be completed within 3 years. The Secretary must complete studies for potential inclusion into the National Park System within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Studies must involve public input and consider areas with significant natural or cultural resources, recreational opportunities. The Secretary must conduct studies for potential inclusion into the National Park System within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. The study considers areas with nationally significant natural or cultural resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and uniqueness in representing a particular resource type in the country. Factors such as resource rarity, threats, existing protections, public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, and acquisition costs are considered in the study. The study for potential inclusion into the National Park System considers factors such as resource rarity, threats, existing protections, public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and appropriate management options. The study aims to identify the most effective and efficient way to protect significant resources. Service management or alternative protection by other agencies or the private sector is appropriate for the area. Each study shall identify the most effective and efficient way to protect significant resources and provide for public enjoyment. The Secretary shall submit a list of areas previously studied with cultural or historical resources to Congress annually. The Secretary shall annually submit to Congress a list of areas previously studied containing primarily cultural or historical resources and another list containing primarily natural resources for potential addition to the National Park System, considering various factors. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 28, 1994, as attested by DONNALD K. ANDERSON, Clerk.
